facts.text: The appeals arise from the judgment and order dated August 29, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Election Petition No. 18 of 1967.

facts.text: Rajaram Singh filed an election petition under Section 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 challenging the election of Kishorilal from Bhander Assembly Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: We shall give the facts of A. No. 2123/69 which arises from an election petition filed by the respondent Rajaram Singh an unsuccessful candidate in the High

facts.text: Kishorilal was declared duly elected from Bhander Assembly Constituency in February 1967.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant who was declared duly elected in February 1967 from the Bhander Assembly Constituency of the State of Madhya Pradesh-a seat which was reserve

facts.text: Last date for filing nomination papers was January 20, 1967.

facts.text: Date of scrutiny of nominations was January 21, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: the date of scrutiny was January 21, 1967. The pool took place on February 20, 1967.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 20, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The pool took place on February 20, 1967. The result of the election was declared on February 21, 1967.

facts.text: Election result declared on February 21, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the election was declared on February 21, 1967. The appellant obtained 24,549 votes whereas respondent No. 1 obtained 8096 votes.

facts.text: Kishorilal obtained 24,549 votes and Rajaram Singh obtained 8,096 votes.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court held that Kishorilal belongs to the Jatav caste.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found sub-issue  a  in the affirmative and held that the appellant belonged to the Jatav caste.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court held that Kishorilal did not possess the necessary qualifications to contest as a scheduled caste candidate.

anchor.surface_text: On sub-issue  b  it was held that the appellant did number possess the necessary qualifications and was, therefore, unqualified to fill the in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order 1950 and Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes Lists (Modification) Order 1956 list Chamar etc. but exclude Jatav in Datia district; candidate resident there per electoral roll

holdings.text: no inquiry could be made into whether Jatav is sub-caste of or same as Chamar; not open to lead evidence that non-notified caste is same as notified scheduled caste
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 341 empowers President to specify castes by locality; precedents in Bhaiyalal v. Harikishan Singh and Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa prohibit equivalence inquiries

holdings.text: returned candidate not entitled to contest as scheduled caste candidate from Bhander despite Jatav recorded there, as permanent resident of Bargawan in Seondha (Datia district) where Jatav not scheduled caste

holdings.text: test of residence under Art. 341 and Presidential Orders leads to highly anomalous and unjust results but scheme upheld as per precedents

anchor.surface_text: This test of residence leads to highly anomalous and unjust results which can be illustrated by a simple example. If there are two brothers belonging to Jatav caste

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical examples show brothers same caste different SC status by district; bound by Bhaiyalal precedent despite if res integra difficulties reconciling with Art. 341

anchor.surface_text: Bhaiyalal v. Harikishan Singh others 1 made observations repelling the contention that under Art. 341 of the Constitution the President was not authorised to limit the specification to parts of a State.

precedents.cited_proposition: under Art. 341 of the Constitution the President was authorised to limit the specification to parts of a State; plea that Dohar caste is sub-caste of Chamar cannot be accepted and inquiry not permissible under Art. 341
precedents.cited_holding: the plea that though the appellant was not a Chamar as such he could claim the same status by reason of the fact that he belonged to Dohar caste which is a sub-caste of the Chamar caste could not be accepted. An inquiry of that kind would not be permissible having regard to the provisions contained in Art. 341 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Basavalingappa v. Munichinnappa 2 was referred to. In that case it was laid down that generally speaking it was not open to any person to lead evidence to establish that his caste includes or is the same as another caste which is notified in the Order.

precedents.cited_proposition: generally speaking it was not open to any person to lead evidence to establish that his caste includes or is the same as another caste which is notified in the Order
precedents.cited_holding: it was laid down that generally speaking it was not open to any person to lead evidence to establish that his caste includes or is the same as another caste which is notified in the Order.
